Literature Review: Genetically engineered (GE) crops that produce insecticidal toxins derived from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) have become a cornerstone in the management of insect pests in the United States. These crops, primarily corn and cotton, have been engineered to express Bt toxins that target specific pests, leading to significant reductions in pest populations and associated benefits such as decreased use of conventional insecticides and increased agricultural profitability. The deployment of Bt crops has had varying outcomes across different regions and pest species. In some cases, the introduction of Bt crops has led to the regional suppression of pest populations and even pest eradication. These successes have been attributed to the high efficacy of Bt toxins and the reduced reliance on chemical insecticides, which can disrupt natural enemy populations and lead to secondary pest outbreaks. However, the effectiveness of Bt crops is not without challenges. One of the most significant issues is the evolution of resistance in pest populations. Several factors contribute to the evolution of resistance in pest populations. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) is another crucial component in the sustainable use of Bt crops. The success of Bt crops in managing insect pests also depends on the specific pest-crop interactions and the ecological context. In conclusion, Bt crops have played a significant role in the management of insect pests in the United States, leading to regional pest suppression and economic benefits for farmers. To maintain the effectiveness of Bt crops, it is imperative to implement robust resistance management strategies and integrate Bt crops into comprehensive IPM programs. By learning from past experiences and adopting a multifaceted approach to pest management, the agricultural community can continue to benefit from the advantages of Bt crops while minimizing the risks of resistance development.
